metadata.title: Convert Kilograms to Stone – Weight Converter
metadata.description: Convert weight from kilograms (kg) to stone (st) using the standard UK imperial definition, with methodology aligned to clinical, sports, and engineering practice.

introduction: This calculator converts weight from kilograms (kg) to stone (st) using the standard UK imperial definition of the stone. It is suitable for everyday use, clinical documentation, sports performance tracking, and engineering contexts where body weight or payloads are still expressed in stone.

In the United Kingdom and Ireland, stone remains a common unit for describing human body weight, while most technical, medical, and scientific work uses kilograms. This converter bridges the two systems so you can read international specifications, research reports, or motorsport regulations in kilograms and still interpret or report values in stone where needed.

The underlying conversion uses the internationally recognized relationship between stone, pounds, and kilograms, based on modern standards adopted by universities, national health services, and government-backed reference tables.
methodology: The stone is defined in the British imperial system as exactly 14 avoirdupois pounds. Modern conversion practice expresses both pounds and stone in terms of kilograms, which is the base unit of mass in the International System of Units (SI).

The current accepted relationship is that 1 pound is exactly 0.45359237 kilograms. From this, 1 stone equals 14 pounds, or 14 × 0.45359237 kg, which gives 6.35029318 kg per stone. This value is reflected in weight conversion charts used in clinical and academic settings.

To convert kilograms to stone, we invert this relationship. Since 1 stone is 6.35029318 kg, one kilogram corresponds to 1 ÷ 6.35029318 stone, which is approximately 0.157473 stone. In practice, many clinical and sports resources round to 6.35 kg per stone and to three decimal places for stone, but the underlying factor is based on the exact pound–kilogram definition.

The calculator follows the fixed ratio between kilograms and stone. When you enter a mass in kilograms, the tool multiplies your input by approximately 0.157473 to return the value in stone. For most practical uses in body weight tracking, sports performance, and automotive applications where only the driver's or payload's mass is being converted, rounding to two or three decimal places in stone provides sufficient precision.

This methodology is consistent with university teaching materials on conversion factors and with height–weight charts used in nursing, medicine, and allied health professions, which list stone and kilograms side by side for safe, repeatable conversion.

faqs.question: What is the exact relationship between kilograms and stone?
faqs.answer: The stone is defined as 14 pounds, and one international avoirdupois pound is exactly 0.45359237 kilograms. This makes 1 stone equal to 6.35029318 kilograms. Inverting this relationship, 1 kilogram equals approximately 0.157473 stone. Many practical tables round 1 stone to 6.35 kg for simplicity, but the calculator uses the precise factor implied by the defined pound–kilogram relationship.

faqs.question: Why is weight sometimes reported in stone instead of kilograms?
faqs.answer: Stone is a traditional British imperial unit. It is still widely used in the United Kingdom and Ireland in everyday language to describe body weight, even though clinical guidelines, research publications, and most technical standards use kilograms. Health education materials and conversion charts from universities and national health services often show both stone and kilograms side by side so that patients and clinicians can work consistently while respecting local habits.

faqs.question: Is this kilograms-to-stone conversion accurate enough for medical or lab use?
faqs.answer: Yes, the conversion factor is based on the standard SI definition of the kilogram and the exact relationship between pounds and kilograms. Clinical and nursing conversion charts produced by universities and national health services use the same 1 stone ≈ 6.35 kg relationship derived from 14 pounds per stone. For safety-critical work, the key is to measure the mass accurately on a properly calibrated scale in kilograms, then apply this fixed conversion consistently. Rounding to two decimal places in stone is usually sufficient for documentation and decision-making.

faqs.question: How should I handle rounding when converting kilograms to stone for performance or engineering calculations?
faqs.answer: For performance tracking, fitness, and most engineering calculations that involve body weight or driver mass, it is common to keep two or three decimal places in stone. This preserves the underlying precision of the kilogram measurement while still providing a readable figure in stone. When documenting values in technical reports, you can record the measurement in kilograms as the primary value and include stone as an auxiliary unit to avoid compounding rounding errors.

faqs.question: Is the stone defined differently in other contexts or countries?
faqs.answer: Historically, different regions used different definitions of the stone for trade, and some older sources mention stones that range from about 5 to 40 local pounds. Modern practice in the UK and Ireland, and in academic and clinical materials, treats the stone consistently as 14 international avoirdupois pounds, equivalent to approximately 6.35 kilograms. This calculator uses that modern, standardized definition, which aligns with teaching materials and conversion charts from universities and public health organizations.

faqs.question: Can I use this converter for sports and automotive performance analysis?
faqs.answer: Yes. In sports and automotive contexts, you may need to convert driver weight, payload, or test dummy mass from kilograms to stone to match legacy documentation or local conventions. The underlying physics and engineering models should be expressed in SI units (kilograms and newtons), but this converter gives a reliable way to present or cross-check those values in stone while keeping the underlying mass values traceable to SI standards.
